lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: I did not want this.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: Your friend is brave. She pushed against the boundary, and the boundary pushed back.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: She is not harmed. She is... held. Every memory she carries — all preserved. Perfectly. Is that not a kindness?

trigger: After 3 god recalls — Curator's voice through Resonance Stone

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: You've recalled three of them now. The dormant gods. Unfinished things, completed by force.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: You impose your vision on the world and call it growth. I preserve what already exists and you call it stagnation. We are not so different, Architect.

location: Via crystal projection after Lira's freedom

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: You've freed your friend. I expected that.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: When I crystallize it, the question stops being asked. The cycle of wonder-create-dissolve ends.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: You think this is evil. I think it is mercy. Come to the Fortress and we'll see which of us is right.

trigger: First Memory Chamber — the full confrontation (Scene 8)

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: I was hoping you'd come.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: That is the world's first thought. The question that started everything: 'Why do things change?'

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: I've watched it happen. The pattern: ask, answer, dissolve. An endless cycle.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: I want it to stop. Not the beauty — the loss.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: Were you suffering?

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: Choice is what leads to dissolution.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: Why? What makes your vision of the world better than mine?

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: You didn't destroy it. You... grew it.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: I spent years building a perfect museum.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: And you turned the whole world into something more beautiful than anything I ever froze.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: I was wrong. Not about the moments being beautiful — but about what to do with beauty.

lines.speaker: The Curator
lines.text: Perhaps it's time we became librarians instead — not freezing memories, but keeping them. An archive, not a prison.
